title: Serif font with a small hyphen?
content:
I'm looking for a free serif font that has a short (low-profile) hyphen. I am creating an open source font for Gregorian chant ( [http://www.marello.org/projects/caeciliae](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022052741/http:/www.marello.org/projects/caeciliae "http://www.marello.org/projects/caeciliae")) and I am interested in recommending other free fonts that would work well for the accompanying text. Some very basic requirements:

- short hyphen (these come up a lot in the chant text, and smaller = less obtrusive)
- acute accented æ and œ if possible (in case those don't come out correctly, they're ae and oe ligatures)
- other standard ligatures would be a great plus

I like Cardo, but wow: it has a long hyphen.

Thanks for any thoughts or recommendations. -B. Matthew
author: phatmatt

comments.content:
Well, regarding the long hyphen in Cardo, you could horizontally compress its hyphen to the size you want (if that's possible in whatever program you're working in). Since it's just a straight horizontal line in Cardo, there shouldn't be any distortion as there normally is when compressing or expanding glyphs.

A free font that I've heard good things about is [Gentium](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022052741/http:/scripts.sil.org/cms/scripts/page.php?site_id=nrsi&item_id=Gentium), but I don't know whether its hyphen is any shorter.

Here is gentium (words copied from the link you gave)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022052741im_/http:/typophile.com/files/gentium_6076.gif)
  
The ae and oe ligatures are there as well as ae accented.

An additional remark: Gentium comes in roman and italics only . You can find (pdf) specimen and proofs at the bottom of this [link](http://web.archive.org/web/20131022052741/http:/scripts.sil.org/cms/scripts/page.php?site_id=nrsi&item_id=Gentium_download).

[edit] I mean there is just one weight (there is no bold roman, no bold italics)
